Dear Mr. Roach,
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 For repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and
your contract.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. If I am not available and you need to speak to someone immediately, please
contact the local office at (248) 975-5053.

II. ALLEGATION:
Violation
Established?
On 7/11/21, Youth J flipped over a couch and fell in the cottage. No
Former Staff 1 put him in a bearhug implying improper restraint.
Former Staff 1 put Youth J outside where he stayed for three
hours implying inappropriate discipline.
ADDITIONAL FINDINGS: Yes
Methodist did not follow their CPI staff training policy
Methodist was out of ratio on 7/11/21 per their contract with DHHS
III. METHODOLOGY
07/13/2021 Special Investigation Intake
2021C0108045
07/13/2021 Special Investigation Initiated - Telephone
Coordinated with Government Worker
07/14/2021 Contact - Face to Face
Interviewed Youth J; Staff 2; Supervisor 1
07/19/2021 Contact - Telephone call received
Joint interview of Former Staff 1 with Gov't Worker 1
07/20/2021 Contact – Requested and rec’d staff training record and other
staffing info on 7/11/21
07/21/2021 Contact – Requested and rec’d Methodist CPI training
policy/modules
07/22/2021 Pre-Exit Conference with Administrator 1
ALLEGATION:
On 7/11/21, Youth J flipped over a couch and fell in the cottage. Former Staff 1 put
him in a bearhug implying improper restraint. Former Staff 1 put Youth J outside
where he stayed for three hours implying inappropriate discipline.
2

INVESTIGATION:
I interviewed Youth J, age 15, jointly with Government Worker 1. He has been at
the facility for just five days. Youth J said he has ADHD and mentioned he likes to
“fight/box.” He was hyperverbal and blended his words together. His thoughts were
disorganized, and he was unable to present information in chronological order.
On 7/11/21, Youth J said he and another youth were held back from an outing due to
their behavior. When his peers returned from the outing, he said “Two kids hit me. I
was bumping my back against the wall for no reason.” Former Staff 1 redirected the
boys. “She (Former Staff 1) told me if I wanted to do that, I could leave and
threatened to put me out. She bearhugged me. I flipped the couch. She lifted me
up and put me outside.” Asked to clarify, Youth J claimed Former Staff 1 physically
lifted him up off the floor, walked with him out the exit door and set him outside on
his feet.
While outdoors, Youth J said Supervisor 1 talked to him “for a long time.” They
waited for Former Staff 1 to get off work and Supervisor 1 let him back into the
cottage.
After being “put out” of his cottage, initially Youth J admitted he never attempted to
get back inside because he knew he would not be let in. Then he changed his story,
stating he repeatedly knocked on the door trying to get in. At this point of the
interview, Youth J mumbled, “I’m a liar and a thief.”
Former Staff 1 no longer works at the facility. According to Director 1, she had no
disciplinary record. Former Staff 1 worked at Methodist for eight months and
resigned on 7/12/21. I interviewed Former Staff 1 jointly with Government Worker 1
via telephone. She told us she never intended to resign but was asked to sign a
resignation letter after she complained to Human Resources that she “did not feel
valued as an employee.” Former Staff 1 said her resignation was unrelated to the
incident under investigation in this report.
Former Staff 1 was asked to recall the afternoon of 7/11/21. She said Youth J was
disruptive to peers, physically destructive and verbally abusive to staff. Youth J left
the cottage without permission at 3pm, Staff 2 intervened, Youth J returned,
apologized, and picked up the mess he had made. After that, Former Staff 1 said “I
sat with Youth J for hours. He was fine until his peers returned from an outing with
Subway (fast food). Youth J had already eaten and was upset.” Former Staff 1 said
she explained to him that the fast food was a treat that came with the privilege of
qualifying for the outing.
Later during shower time (7 – 7:30pm), Former Staff 1 said Youth J was “teasing
and agitating” his peers. Staff tried to redirect him. Youth J banged on a peer’s door
3

and “cursed me.” Staff 2 directed him to his room. “Youth J ran around, flipping
couches and jumped the counter onto chairs…We tried to ignore some of the
behaviors. He walked into my personal space calling me the ‘N’ and ‘B’ words.”
Former Staff 1 suggested Youth J go outdoors to cool down. “He asked for his
shoes and threw them at the door. I left the area. When I returned, he had gone
outside to the playscape. We (Former Staff 1 and Staff 2) watched him from the
window. He returned with the hose on and started spraying the building with water.
He did not respond to redirection. He threatened to tell his worker I abused him. I
went outside and asked if he wanted to come inside. He said ‘No’ and that he would
tell his worker I made him stay outside. I told him to let us know when he wanted to
come back in. He told Supervisor 1 that I abused him. Supervisor 1 talked to him
outside until about 9pm.” Former Staff 1 said she was working at 9:30pm when
Youth J returned with the supervisor, showered, and went to bed.
I interviewed Staff 2 jointly with Government Worker 1. He has worked at the facility
for five months and has 13 years of experience working in a secure child caring
institution. Staff 2 told us he had not received CPI training at Methodist since he
was hired in Feb 2021. Rather than physically intervene with youth, Staff 2 said they
call the police if youth require physical intervention. I checked Staff 2’s Orientation
Training record. It showed 1.75 hrs. of CPI training and 2.0 hrs. of child discipline
training. (See additional finding)
Staff 2 said he worked with Former Staff 1 on 7/11/21. When five youth and one
staff returned from an outing, he said Youth J started agitating a peer, flipped the
furniture and became verbally abusive toward Former Staff 1. Former Staff 1
suggested he go outdoors for a walk. “She escorted him toward the door, got his
shoes and he went outside.”
Staff 2 said he stood in the cottage doorway and watched Youth J while he was
outside. Youth J started destroying property. “I redirected him and disconnected the
water hose. He was banging on the cottage door and windows. It got to raining
hard. He walked to the playscape. He stayed outside for 30 or 40 minutes. Staff 2
tended showers inside the cottage while Supervisor 1 talked to Youth J outside.
Staff 2 said Former Staff 1 never put Youth J in a “bearhug” or small-child restraint.
She also did not physically lift him off the floor and “put” him outside. Staff 2 said
Youth J left the cottage on his own and never asked to come back in until he
returned with Supervisor 1.
I interviewed Supervisor 1 jointly with Government Worker 1. He has worked at
Methodist for one year and is a CPI instructor. Around 9:30pm, Supervisor 1 said he
was in his office when he saw Youth J outdoors trying to break a window in the
administrative building. Former Staff 1 was outdoors monitoring the youth from a
distance. Supervisor 1 sat down with Youth J and had a conversation outside.
4

During their talk, Supervisor 1 said the youth never told him that Former Staff 1
restrained or disciplined him inappropriately. “He (Youth J) vented and then wanted
to go back to his cottage.”
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.159 Resident restraint.
(1) An institution shall establish and follow written policies
and procedures regarding restraint. These policies and
procedures shall be available to all residents, their families,
and referring agencies.
ANALYSIS: Based on the interviews, there is no evidence Former Staff 1
physically managed or restricted Youth J’s movement in any
way. There is also no evidence Former Staff 1 lifted Youth J off
the floor and physically placed him outside.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4158 Discipline.
(2) An institution shall prohibit all cruel and severe
discipline, including any of the following:
(h) Denial of shelter, clothing, or essential personal
needs.
ANALYSIS: On the night of 7/11/21, it was determined Youth J left his
cottage voluntarily after Former Staff 1 suggested he go
outdoors to calm down. The youth engaged in destructive
behaviors both inside and outside the cottage. He eventually
settled down while talking with a supervisor. There was no
evidence any staff “put” him out or denied him access back into
the cottage.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
ADDITIONAL FINDINGS:
Staff 2 is a youth specialist hired in Feb 2021. His Orientation Training record
indicates he has 1.75 hrs. - CPI training and 2.0 hrs. - child discipline training. There
5

was no record he is CPI certified or had any additional physical management
training since February.
The facility’s residential policy section F.9 indicates “The CPI model has ten (10)
units which are taught over a two (2) day period to all youth specialists.” Staff 2 did
not have the two-day CPI training written in the agency’s physical
management/restraint training policy.
APPLICABLE RULE
Rule 2. Prohibition of Prone Restraint; Procedures Involving Other
Restraints in Child Caring Institutions
The written policy must include all of the following:
(f) Procedures for the provision of sufficient and adequate
training for all staff members of the CCI who may use or
order the use of restraint using the CCI’s written
procedures.
ANALYSIS: The agency’s policy pertaining to CPI training indicates there
are ten modules taught to all youth specialists over a two-day
period. Staff 2 was hired in Feb 2021 and as of July 2021, he
had not had two days of CPI training.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The staff training model that utilizes CPI techniques for physical
restraint & TCI techniques for verbal de-escalation was
approved by the department in 2017. The approved model and
techniques should reflect the agency’s current practice and be
consistent with the agency’s written policies. If the agency
wishes to change their crisis intervention techniques and/or staff
training model, this must first be approved by the
department.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
ADDITIONAL FINDINGS:
Staff 2 stated that Staff 3 took five youth on an outing to the movies on 7/11/21 and
Director 1 confirmed this.
Methodist contracts with DHHS for treatment and shelter beds. Both contracts
require a staff-to-youth ratio of 1 staff for every 4 youth. The facility was out of ratio
on 7/11/21 when Staff 3 took five youth off the grounds on an outing.
6

APPLICABLE RULE
RFCAN/RFCJJ 1. General Residential
Staffing Ratio
The Contractor must:
a. Provide a minimum of one on-duty direct care worker for
every four youth during waking hours.
ANALYSIS: The agency’s contract indicates they are required to have a 1:4
ratio and they were out of ratio on 7/11/21.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Once an acceptable corrective action plan is received, I recommend this facility
continue its Regular License.
